ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I greatly increased my Greek skills, reading both Attic and Ionic dialects. I expanded my vocabulary while also learning about how to produce a more nuanced translation. I also learned new strategies for language-learning that I can apply to other languages. I became more familiar with using Greek resources fluently to support my reading.
Greek translation, analysis of classical literature
Improved my knowledge of Ancient Greek grammar and was exposed to the histories of Herodotus, philosophy of Plato, and science fiction of Lucian in the original language.

This course further developed my understanding of Greek language and grammar, particularly in the context of longer works of prose. Additionally, the course really helped teach me different kinds of approaches to interacting with and translating ancient texts.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I don't know how to improve this course. It probably would've been more engaging if we were all sitting in the same physical room together, but other than that, it was really good.
Great professor and very engaging, throughtful discussions in class - could improve on some general organiztional elements

Strengths: small class size to maximize individual participation, meeting three times a week to focus on repetition of grammar 

Weaknesses: none
The course was very well taught and paced in a way that really helped students succeed.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class is particularly well suited for Zoom-based learning. There were very few of us, so everyone had a chance to participate regularly.
Zoom learning worked very well for this language course, and I would say that virtual language learning during a pandemic did not take a toll like courses in other subjects.

I appreciated how the course offered quizzes/tests in a manner reflective of the different time zones we were all in, so that one did not necessarily have to take them at the same time as the course was taught.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course.
Absolutely! L3 Greek is a great transition course between honing in your grammar skills while at the same time exploring the actual language itself in real texts, such as Plato, Herodotus, or Lucian.
This course is an excellent step if one wishes to improve their knowledge of the Greek language.
